comment._content: It looks more like a prison camp.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] That's true and I've also seen pictures of tailors working in a similar position. Wonder why they work in that seemingly uncomfortable position? How long can they sit like that on hard wooden flooring?

Now, I'm surmising here....it would be nice to know if the man standing to our right is Mr Hearne himself and the other two to the left perhaps clerks? The man standing near the centre could possibly be the shop governor (foreman) and looks to be a hard task-master?

Heating? If there's no fireplace then a couple of paraffin (kerosene) heaters. But without adequate ventilation the room would be very stuffy and nauseous, leading to headaches.

comment._content: it's sad still the conditions they were working with. They are all wearing heavy suits, couldn't be comfortable sitting all day with those on, but I guess that is the attire for the time.

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
My great granfather was a tailor and worked sitting crossed legged like this on a large table in front of a window.
My great grandmother and the children would help by sewing buttonholes
He was my grandfather's father, and besides his job he also played the base fiddle in a theatre orchestra in Glasgow.

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/tammybeck] As you say it was the attire of the time: my own grandfather (tha tailor's son) always wore a tie, even when repairing his car in his garage (when a tie got old he'd say "This one will do for going to the garage!").
My other great grandfather was a railway plumber in the south of Scotland, he also wore his tie full time and would go to work on his bicycle with his denim overalls wrapped in a brown paper parcel, he wouln't have been seen dead wearing them in the street!
I wonder what he'd say nowadays that denims have become day to day garments!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrick_castelli] He'd probably have been horrified, as every generation is horrified by those that come after! I think that's some kind of universal law... Both of your great grandfathers sound like real characters... #1 = Tailor by day, orchestra musician by night. #2 = Railway man, inveterate tie-wearer
